author: sky.cactus
content: I think I'm on the fence for this.  A system with privileged sequencers is definitely a "permissioned system", (by definition).  For me, the purpose of censorship resistance is to ensure that the system can function even in the face of state level censorship.  A permissioned system I don't think can stand up to that.  It can fail gracefully (which a well designed L2 should), but it isn't actually censorship resistant IMO.

author: .vbuterin
content: Optimism already has an on-chain sequencer bypass solution I think

author: .vbuterin
content: Maybe arbitrum does too?

author: sky.cactus
content: Importantly, someone could force anyone who wants to use the system to do so on L1 at higher cost than those who use it on L2.  If the costs of using it on L1 are sufficiently higher than the cost of using it on L2 then one can imagine an equilibrium where people who aren't censored continue to use the platform on L2 at low cost, while those who are censored are forced to pay a significantly higher price to use it on L1.

author: sky.cactus
content: Is it a permissioned takeover sort of thing?

author: .vbuterin
content: Oh no it's not a takeover

author: .vbuterin
content: It's a "force my op onto an on-chain list, where the sequencer is required to include it in the next batch" thing

author: sky.cactus
content: A strategy for selecting a new permissioned sequencer if the previous one disappears?

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, yeah.  I think both have that as a feature.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't personally think that is a viable long term solution though.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just as a thought experiment, imagine if Twitter said "you aren't censored, but it will cost you $100 to Tweet while everyone else gets to Tweet for free".

author: sky.cactus
content: That would be a very effective way of censoring the content produced by a particular user, even if technically the user could "work around it".

author: .vbuterin
content: Right, so I have been thinking about this in a different context (on-chain PBS)

author: .vbuterin
content: And I'm fairly convinced you can make a stable market where multiple censored users can band together and all pay fees to a secondary includer that batches their ops

author: sky.cactus
content: The idea is that the permissioned sequencer is a meta-sequencer?

author: .vbuterin
content: So the "sequencer" is a privileged actor that can include ops that get executed with 0 delay

author: sky.cactus
content: But anyone can publish a batch of pre-sequenced transactions that must be included in order (or perhaps out of order, order may not matter here)?

author: .vbuterin
content: Anyone else can permissionlessly be a batcher that includes ops that get executed with N delay

author: sky.cactus
content: Good for things that don't have high time preference (where time preference is lower than `n`).

author: .vbuterin
content: Right, though you can set N to be fairly low, eg. even N = 1 slot could work

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.

author: .vbuterin
content: There's the question of whether or not the secondary batcher market is stable because the batcher doesn't know if an op will pay fees

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming you *also* have a mechanism for replacing a sequencer that disappears for a sufficiently long period of time, I think this could be a reasonable solution.

author: .vbuterin
content: I have been thinking about that lately

author: .vbuterin
content: https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/pbs_censorship_resistance#Experimental-Secondary-builder-strategies

author: .vbuterin
content: This is still a draft doc

author: .vbuterin
content: But I'm convinced that there are enough secondary batcher strategies available that it can work

author: sky.cactus
content: I currently would personally rather a solution that can support permissionless sequencers via some sort of game or rotation system.  I think allowing the cost savings of batching by anyone, but final ordering being permissioned, is a reasonable alternative though as long as you have a recovery mechanism should permissioned sequencer disappear.

author: jgm
content: (Is anyone else feeling that the whole transaction ordering / MEV / builder-proposer separation stuff is becoming a sledgehammer to crack a nut?  Not that I have any particular solution, or indeed feel for how big a nut we're talking about, but it does seem to be potentially adding a huge amount of complexity that will be unnecessary when the majority of transactions move to layer 2.)

author: .vbuterin
content: When txs move to layer 2 it'll be a problem at layer 2 as well, and the solutions will end up similar

author: .vbuterin
content: And even in a layer 2 world, layer 1 MEV may well still be big enough that the centralization risks of it being unresolved are terrible

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is value in doing the research and having a solution.  I'm not yet convinced we need to implement the solution immediately though.

author: .vbuterin
content: Also, BPS has other benefits, particularly in allowing validators to be stateless

author: sky.cactus
content: If we had the ability to delivery a solution "in the next hard fork" I think I would be generally satisfied in ignoring the problem until such time as we actually need the solution, or we have some free time to go and implement it.

author: sky.cactus
content: (I say this somewhat glibly, I haven't thought hard about it)

author: jgm
content: Agree that there will always be MEV somewhere, just worried that by the time layer 1 has mitigated it there wont be enough for anyone to care.  As for centralization risks, do we really not have enough mitigation already in place with the existing mechanisms (_e.g._ validator deposits and slashing thereof)?

author: jgm
content: (re: validator statelessness: that's just breaking down the roles, not sure that validators _per se_ do that much anyway so not sure that it is a useful separation.)
